title: Dehydration in Children
summary: Children dehydrate quickly from vomiting, diarrhea, or fever. Requires prompt fluid replacement to prevent serious complications.

steps.title: Recognize Dehydration Signs
steps.description: Mild: dry mouth, few tears when crying, decreased urination. Moderate: sunken eyes, lethargy, no tears. Severe: very sleepy, sunken fontanel (baby), no wet diapers for 8+ hours.

steps.title: Start Oral Rehydration
steps.description: For mild dehydration, give oral rehydration solution (Pedialyte) or clear fluids. Start with 1 teaspoon every 5 minutes. Gradually increase amount. Avoid juice and soda. Breast milk is best for infants.

steps.title: Use Proper Fluids
steps.description: Best: oral rehydration solutions, breast milk. Good: clear broth, popsicles, diluted apple juice. Avoid: full-strength juice, soda, sports drinks (too much sugar). Give small amounts frequently.

steps.title: Monitor Hydration Status
steps.description: Count wet diapers or bathroom trips. Check if tears present when crying. Pinch skin - should snap back quickly. Weigh child if possible - weight loss indicates fluid loss.

steps.title: Know When to Seek Help
steps.description: Call doctor if: no improvement after 4 hours, blood in stool/vomit, high fever, signs worsen. Go to ER for: extreme sleepiness, no urination for 8+ hours, dry mouth with no saliva.

warnings: Infants and toddlers dehydrate much faster than older children
Never force fluids if child is actively vomiting - wait 30-60 minutes
Severe dehydration can cause seizures and shock
whenToSeekHelp: See doctor for moderate dehydration signs
Go to ER if child is very lethargic or not urinating
Call 911 if child is unresponsive or having seizures
preventionTips: Keep oral rehydration solution at home
